baseline_groups.claim_summary: Mission-based incentives (no bonus) increase the probability that a household is visited by a Lady Health Worker.
baseline_groups.notes: Single baseline specification from Table 1 Column 1: panel regression of lhw_visit on treatment dummies with block + wave FE, household weights, clustered at lhw_id level. Coefficient of 0.051 (SE=0.012, p<0.001) represents a 5.1pp increase in visit probability relative to control.

global_notes: Clean specification search with 55 specs. One clear baseline. The spec search includes several categories of non-core tests: alternative outcomes (pregnant served, child served, TB check, diarrhea incidence, vaccination schedule), alternative treatment arms (financial incentive, mission+bonus, social recognition placebo), heterogeneity subsamples (community size terciles), and conditional-on-visit outcomes. Two specs appear to be exact duplicates (robust/weights/unweighted and robust/method/tabA4_unweighted have identical coefficients). The heterogeneity interaction specs (26-31) report the main treatment coefficient while adding interaction controls, making them interpretable as controls variations. The community size tercile splits (49-51) and baseline-performance splits (8-9) are sample splits that test the effect in subgroups; the former are classified as heterogeneity because they split the sample along a dimension the paper highlights as showing differential effects, while the latter are classified as core sample restrictions because they test whether the effect holds across performance groups.
